Virgil had been feeling more anxious than ever before. Despite his regular age regression sessions with Roman, he just couldn't seem to shake the feeling of fear that had been building up inside him.

One day, as he was walking through the park, he suddenly felt a sense of panic rising up inside him. He tried to control it, but it quickly became too much for him to handle. He sat down on a bench and started to cry, feeling more vulnerable than ever before.

"Hey, what's wrong?" a voice asked, interrupting his thoughts.

Virgil looked up to see Janus standing in front of him, his face etched with concern. Janus was a friend of Roman's, and Virgil had met him a few times before, but he didn't know him well.

"I...I don't know," Virgil said, his voice shaking with fear. "I just feel so scared."

Janus sat down next to Virgil, wrapping his arms around him in a comforting hug. "It's okay," he said, using his soft, soothing voice. "I'm here for you."

With those words, Virgil allowed himself to regress even further, slipping into a younger age than he had ever experienced before. Janus held him close, playing with him using toys and stuffed animals, and singing him gentle lullabies to help him calm down.

As the day wore on, Virgil found himself feeling more and more like a little child, needing help with even the most basic tasks. Janus was there for him every step of the way, helping him to eat, drink, and even change his incontinence aids when he needed it.

At first, Virgil was embarrassed by his dependence on Janus, but as the days went on, he found himself growing more and more comfortable with the idea of being taken care of. He felt safe and loved in Janus's care, and he knew that he could always rely on him to be there for him, no matter what.

As the weeks passed, Virgil slowly started to regain his sense of independence. He still needed Janus's help with some tasks, but he was able to do more and more things on his own. And through it all, Janus remained a constant source of support and encouragement, always ready to help him when he needed it most.

In the end, Virgil knew that he had made a real connection with Janus, and that he would always be grateful for the care and kindness that he had shown him during his time of need. And with that thought, Virgil felt a sense of peace wash over him, knowing that he had found a new friend in Janus, someone who would always be there for him, no matter what.
